receiver: Chief Executive Officer South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust

concern_responses.concern: The NHS Pathways system categorises all overdoses under the same classification, resulting in the same disposition and response category regardless of the type, severity, or drugs/chemicals involved in the overdose.

action_phrases: Should national guidance or standards be amended such that toxic substances impact ambulance categorisation, NHS England would align NHS Pathways accordingly.

responses.respondent: South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: SECAmb follows updated overdose guidance including clinical review within 30 minutes and use of TOXBASE® for each overdose incident.

concern_responses.concern: The NHS Pathways system does not differentiate call classification based on the amount ingested, timing of ingestion, or the patient's weight, despite these factors impacting the urgency of care needed to prevent death.

action_phrases: Should national guidance or standards be amended such that toxic substances impact ambulance categorisation, NHS England would align NHS Pathways accordingly.

responses.respondent: South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: SECAmb follows updated overdose guidance including clinical review within 30 minutes and use of TOXBASE® for each overdose incident.

concern_responses.concern: The NHS Pathways system does not account for the time-sensitive nature of treatment effectiveness in cases of [REDACTED] ingestion and does not assign a higher disposition requiring more urgent attendance than category 3.

action_phrases: Should national guidance or standards be amended such that toxic substances impact ambulance categorisation, NHS England would align NHS Pathways accordingly.

responses.respondent: South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: SECAmb follows updated overdose guidance including clinical review within 30 minutes and use of TOXBASE® for each overdose incident.

concern_responses.concern: Clinicians within South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust do not carry Methylene Blue, the antidote to [REDACTED] ingestion, on ambulances as it is not included in national guidance.

responses.respondent: South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: SECAmb reviews medication formulary in line with emerging guidance and will modify protocols as appropriate to maintain patient safety.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: Treatment with Methylene Blue is only available when a patient reaches an acute hospital with an A&E department, but patients often enter cardiac arrest before arrival, and only some areas have ongoing trials where HART vehicles carry this antidote.

responses.respondent: South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: SECAmb remains engaged with NHS ambulance services and will review future recommendations regarding methylene blue use and carriage.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: The taxi driver stated that if similar circumstances arose, he would do nothing different and would still be prepared to leave a passenger in an unsafe location.

action_phrases: Updated the “DR18 Driver Information & Advice” document with clearer guidance on duty-of-care and safe decision-making, issued to all drivers on 3rd January 2025.

concern_responses.concern: No evidence or documentation was available to corroborate that staff were being trained in respect of the protocol to contact the police in such circumstances.

action_phrases: Documented new ‘Driver Incident Procedures’ in “CC002 Call Centre Procedures” and sent updated version to all staff on 3rd January 2025.

Chief Executive, Suffolk and North East Essex Integrated Care Board

concern_responses.concern: Neither the NICE guideline [NG225] nor the Suffolk and North East Essex Health & Social Care Protocol for the Support of Children and Young People in Crisis (Version 21 – January 2023) were applied in relation to the care and treatment extended to Erin in the West Suffolk Hospital Emergency Department during her attendance over the period 31 December 2022 to 1 January 2023.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive, West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Chief Executive, Suffolk and North East Essex Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The failure to apply the NICE guidance and SNEE/SCC policy resulted in a missed opportunity for mental health services to engage early with a vulnerable child who had presented to the Emergency Department having undertaken an act which she described as an overdose.

responses.respondent: Chief Executive, West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Implemented extended Manchester Triage system for under 18s including automatic MHLT referral triggers for overdose cases on E-Care as of two weeks ago

responses.respondent: Chief Executive, Suffolk and North East Essex Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: [no response]

receiver: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust

concern_responses.concern: Despite Lisa's LFTs being grossly elevated, the results were not phoned through by the laboratory staff to the clinical staff once obtained.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
action_phrases: RCOG will review the Royal College of Pathologists' response and ensure communication with members and inclusion in clinical guidance.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: UHBW will set up a task and finish group to implement national guidance on urgent reporting reference ranges for LFTs in pregnancy.
Next revision of guidance will emphasise need to agree local cut offs with clinicians, including for pregnancy.

concern_responses.concern: The Royal College of Pathologists' guidelines for urgent reporting only require notification for ALT above 750, bilirubin above 300, and creatinine above 354, and do not provide different reporting levels for tests taken in pregnant women.

action_phrases: Next revision of guidance will emphasise need to agree local cut offs with clinicians, including for pregnancy.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Written to Royal Colleges to consider report and develop national guidance on LFT urgent reporting thresholds in pregnancy.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
action_phrases: RCOG will review Royal College of Pathologists' response and ensure communication with members and inclusion in clinical guidance.

concern_responses.concern: Pregnancy-specific conditions such as Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP) can be potentially fatal at much lower levels of abnormal LFTs than those set currently by the Royal College of Pathologists.

action_phrases: Support revision of Royal College of Pathologists’ guidelines to incorporate different urgent reporting levels for pregnancy.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
action_phrases: Provide online learning resource outlining key clinical features and management of AFLP.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Written to Royal Colleges to consider report and develop national guidance on LFT urgent reporting thresholds in pregnancy.

concern_responses.concern: There was a delay in diagnosing AFLP and starting appropriate treatment as a result of the current reporting guidelines and lack of urgent communication of elevated LFT results.

responses.respondent: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
action_phrases: Emphasise importance of escalation and multidisciplinary working in clinical guidance and quality improvement resources.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Will implement national guidance on urgent LFT reporting via a task and finish group once available.
Next revision of guidance will emphasise need to agree local cut offs with clinicians, including for pregnancy.

receiver: The Chief Executive Officer of University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
The Chief Executive Officer of George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust

concern_responses.concern: Non-specialist medical staff may have varied understanding of the appropriate contacts and timing for engaging with specialist renal hospitals.

responses.respondent: University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Produced laminated quick reference guide with emergency contact numbers for renal services at UHCW displayed across the Trust.
Shared and cascaded renal management guidelines from UHCW with all Directorates to ensure relevant clinical staff awareness.
Recommended all hospital switchboards and Emergency Departments have master copy of local specialist centre contact details for appropriate query direction.
Recommended advising all staff of internal escalation routes to clarify whether off-site specialist input is required.

concern_responses.concern: The specific patient information that non-specialist staff should provide to specialist renal hospitals may not always be clearly defined.

responses.respondent: University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Developed and shared guidelines illustrating sample collection requirements and communication processes with specialist centres.
Implemented guidelines detailing what information to provide and when to liaise with specialist renal centres.

concern_responses.concern: Non-specialist staff may experience varying levels of awareness or accessibility to guidelines and protocols for treating kidney transplant patients, which could lead to a misunderstanding of the significance and urgency of the actions recommended by specialist renal hospitals.

responses.respondent: University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Agreed and cascaded renal care guidelines with GEH, to be placed on UHCW intranet after governance ratification.
Shared renal management guidelines and quick reference guides to improve understanding and urgency of specialist recommendations.

concern_responses.concern: There may be some inconsistency across non-specialist hospitals and renal hospitals in understanding who is responsible for initiating patient transfers.

responses.respondent: University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Established Service Level Agreement for renal specialists to visit GEH twice weekly and lead transfer decisions.
Implemented consultant-to-consultant referral process for transfer decisions based on clinical need.

concern_responses.concern: Considerations regarding whether patients should remain in non-specialist areas or be transferred may differ, potentially affecting consistency in care approaches.

responses.respondent: University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Agreed that renal specialists recommend best location for care, with decisions supported by SLA and guidelines.
Follow consultant-to-consultant discussions to decide patient location based on clinical requirements.

concern_responses.concern: There may be variation in how specialist renal hospitals engage with non-specialist hospitals that rely on their expertise, and currently, there is no clear guidance on how specialist and non-specialist teams should work together effectively to ensure consistent, high-quality care for these patients.

responses.respondent: University Hospital of Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust
action_phrases: Finalised shared guidelines and Service Level Agreement to ensure closer working and improved patient care with GEH.
Collaborated with UHCW to implement shared guidelines and SLA for effective specialist and non-specialist team coordination.

receiver: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council

concern_responses.concern: Communication with service users around moving accommodation needs to be managed carefully as false assurances can undermine trust between the service user and the supporting team.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Create a visual flowchart of the accommodation process to improve communication and manage expectations, to be introduced in February 2025.

concern_responses.concern: Uncertainty in the timescales for moving accommodation is an inherent issue that requires careful management and communication, as it depends on the availability of suitable accommodation.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Include guidance in weekly newsletter from 13th January 2025 to reassure individuals and be person-centred about move timescales.

concern_responses.concern: Those supporting Alison, including community mental health nurses, were unclear on the stage the process had reached, the specific steps of the process, and the likely timescales involved, affecting the type of support they could provide.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Share the accommodation process flowchart with MDT, care providers, family, and friends to clarify stages and timescales from February 2025.

concern_responses.concern: There was a lack of evidence of a specific approach or policy addressing how the moving accommodation process can be clearly communicated to those supporting service users in the community.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Develop and implement a visual flowchart policy for clear communication of the accommodation process by February 2025.

concern_responses.concern: No internal review was carried out at Leicestershire County Council following Alison's death, and if such reviews are not conducted this could lead to inadequate learning from deaths which creates a risk of further deaths.

responses.respondent: Adult Social Care, Leicestershire County Council
action_phrases: Implement a new internal review procedure for unexpected deaths for all Adult Social Care managers from January 2025.

concern_responses.concern: There is a real lack of specialist rehabilitation for women, particularly those who represent only a low or medium risk of harm to others but a high risk of self-harm, with little or no effective system of rehabilitative provision for that cohort.

action_phrases: New initiatives launched including Women’s Justice Board and Women’s Policy Framework to improve outcomes for women in custody and on probation.

concern_responses.concern: The Approved Premises (AP) system is over-subscribed and not well understood as an option for medium risk women, effectively shutting out this cohort from access to APs.

action_phrases: Central Referral Process managed by experienced Female Central Referral Unit Manager to assess AP space needs for women.

concern_responses.concern: Provision for specialist rehabilitation can become dependent on small charities and related acts of individual generosity, leading to patchwork services with unclear access and unclear criteria.

action_phrases: [no response]
Engaged external consultant to review all policies and procedures ensuring a robust framework moving forward.

concern_responses.concern: Despite monitoring by the Probation Service, the situation regarding specialist rehabilitation accommodation for women is worsening, with a continuing gender disparity similar to that found in the Corston review and Coll v SSJ case.

action_phrases: Women’s Justice Board oversight expected to renew focus on accommodation requirements for women in criminal justice system.

concern_responses.concern: Probation officers responsible for finding accommodation and building release plans lack understanding of what accommodation is and is not available, as shown by the failure to realize that an AP might have been available and the failure to appreciate the urgency of finding CAS3 accommodation after the first specialist placement fell through.

action_phrases: From September, Female AP briefings for all practitioners to emphasise availability of AP placements for women with complex needs.

concern_responses.concern: There is a training need for probation officers to improve their knowledge of accommodation options and the implications for support planning.

action_phrases: Central Approved Premises Team promoting community disposals and engaging regional female leads to improve practitioner knowledge.

concern_responses.concern: Steps to Recovery (S2R) has unclear placement offers and conditions, with insufficient clarity around expectations attached to them.

action_phrases: Implemented new ‘Offer/Acceptance’ document clearly communicating placement offers and conditions in writing and verbally.

concern_responses.concern: S2R's recording of decisions around offers, withdrawal, and reconsideration needs improvement to ensure decisions are properly recorded and decision-making is structured and considers all relevant matters.

action_phrases: All communications and decisions recorded on Lamplight case management system and regularly audited by senior management.

concern_responses.concern: Withdrawing accommodation offers without first consulting the requesting organisation, such as prison staff, creates risks and requires greater care due to the critical importance of these decisions.

action_phrases: Contact referring service two weeks prior to client arrival to confirm no changes and consult before withdrawing offers.

receiver: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board

concern_responses.concern: At times when the ambulance service is under extreme pressure, individuals who have fallen at home can wait many hours on the floor before paramedics can attend.

responses.respondent: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: Continue to work as a multi-agency group to try and minimise response times by EMAS during critical incidents.

concern_responses.concern: Falls are given a lower categorisation by the ambulance service because it is not a life-threatening situation, leading to delayed response.

responses.respondent: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: Seek to accelerate the development and roll out of a falls prevention service including consideration of an injurious falls service in 2025/26.

concern_responses.concern: Resultant long lies after falls can increase the risk of pneumonia, pressure damage and rhabdomyolysis.

responses.respondent: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: Seek to implement options that further mitigate the risk of a long lie following a fall available to all residents in Derby & Derbyshire.

concern_responses.concern: Other than the ambulance service, there is no local falls service or team operating out of hours to assess patients and assist them off the floor following a fall.

responses.respondent: NHS Derby & Derbyshire Integrated Care Board
action_phrases: Consider extending DHU falls recovery provision to cover 20:00-08:00 with Team Up and virtual wards providing next day clinical support.

receiver: National Institute for Health & Care Excellence (NICE)

concern_responses.concern: Propranolol continues to be widely prescribed, often to young people reporting symptoms of anxiety, but there is an under-appreciation of the level of risk posed by an elevated level of propranolol medication.

responses.respondent: National Institute for Health & Care Excellence (NICE)
action_phrases: Reviewed evidence and consulted experts to consider updating CG113 guideline on propranolol for anxiety but decided not to update at this time.
Decided not to issue a drug safety update for propranolol after reviewing overdose risks and usage data.

concern_responses.concern: Social ostracism is a recognised practice within student communities, with multiple cases observed and acknowledged by both students and staff, and it may be an issue more broadly for universities in the UK.

action_phrases: Convene a roundtable in early 2025 to explore social ostracism and lack of trust in formal processes in more depth

concern_responses.concern: Students employ social ostracism as a means of 'self-policing' their community, often in response to allegations of serious misconduct, occurring in the absence of formal processes and without proper investigation or evidence.

action_phrases: Convene a roundtable in early 2025 to explore social ostracism and lack of trust in formal processes in more depth

concern_responses.concern: Social ostracism can have severe and lasting negative impacts on mental health, leading to feelings of isolation, shame, guilt, and worthlessness, which are recognised risk factors for suicide.

action_phrases: Provide £15 million funding in 2024/25 via OfS to support mental health and suicide prevention strategies in higher education

concern_responses.concern: The prevalence of social ostracism may be linked to a lack of trust in formal channels for reporting serious concerns, with students perceiving these processes as ineffective, unfair, or biased, leading them to seek alternative means of addressing perceived wrongdoing.

action_phrases: Introduce OfS condition E6 from August 2025 requiring universities to publish harassment policies and ensure fair, sensitive reporting processes

concern_responses.concern: Social ostracism has become normalised within student communities, with individuals viewing it as an expected and accepted response to certain allegations or behaviours, hindering the development of healthy and supportive social environments.

action_phrases: Convene a roundtable in early 2025 to explore social ostracism and lack of trust in formal processes in more depth

concern_responses.concern: The deceased left the hospital on 19 July due to waiting times before being clinically assessed.

action_phrases: Salford Royal Hospital has become an early adopter of the NHSE Acuity Tool to standardize initial assessment and improve patient flow in Emergency Departments.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: There was no consideration of whether secondary investigations, such as a CT scan, could be undertaken during the waiting time.

action_phrases: Secondary investigations like CT scans will be frontloaded for patients meeting NICE guidelines while awaiting clinical review.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: No evidence was provided that the deceased’s capacity to decide to leave the hospital was assessed given the history of suspected head injury.

action_phrases: The new SOP mandates nursing and clinical staff to assess mental capacity for patients wishing to leave and escalate concerns appropriately.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: A new standard operating procedure is being developed relating to patients leaving the hospital before a clinical assessment occurs, but it is unclear what this will include.

action_phrases: A draft SOP for patients leaving before clinical assessment is under NCA approval, detailing staff responsibilities and safeguarding measures, with approval expected by 6 February 2025.
[no response]

President of the Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
President of the Royal College of Surgeons
President of the Royal College of Radiologists

concern_responses.concern: Neither the original GP, the reviewing surgical SHO or surgical registrar considered that Lacey had appendicitis.

action_phrases: Support ongoing educational resources for GP Curriculum and Continuing Professional Development on appendicitis diagnosis.
Publish anonymised educational Surgical Safety vignette and discuss case with NHSE Surgical Safety Lead.

responses.respondent: President Royal, Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: Share report and suggestions for local improvement with paediatric members via patient safety portal.

responses.respondent: President of the Royal College of Radiologists
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The consultant surgeon reviewing Lacey on 24th considered she was ill but could not reach a diagnosis.

action_phrases: Explore explicit reference to retrocaecal appendicitis in CCRISP and Clinical Skills in Emergency Surgery courses by 2025.
[no response]

responses.respondent: President Royal, Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: President of the Royal College of Radiologists
action_phrases: Advocate prompt assessment by experienced clinicians including expert surgeons and radiologists.

concern_responses.concern: Retrocaecal appendicitis presentation is not a rare presentation of either acute appendicitis or generalised abdominal pain (both common presenting features in the young).

action_phrases: Share report with Specialty Advisory Committee Chairs for consideration during curricula reviews.
Highlight retrocaecal appendicitis features in NICE CKS guidance and GP training materials.

responses.respondent: President Royal, Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: Include diagnosis of acute abdominal pain in core paediatric training syllabus and signpost GIRFT Best Practice Pathway.

responses.respondent: President of the Royal College of Radiologists
action_phrases: Advocate using similar imaging strategies for retrocaecal appendicitis as for general appendicitis.

concern_responses.concern: The availability and use of bedside/departmental ultrasound scanning in abdominal pain (e.g. in the young) at any time, but especially out of hours.

responses.respondent: President of the Royal College of Radiologists
action_phrases: Advocate prompt imaging referral and note ultrasound availability varies greatly, with CT available 24/7 in UK hospitals.
Note bedside ultrasound scanning not routinely available in hospital emergency or primary care; policy change and investment needed.
[no response]

responses.respondent: President Royal, Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The training of doctors in considering the diagnosis as a possible differential to generalised abdominal pain.

responses.respondent: President Royal, Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health
action_phrases: Emphasise clinical assessment and differential diagnosis in paediatric training syllabus and share learning via patient safety portal.
Ensure retrocaecal appendicitis diagnosis and management included in surgical curricula and review courses by 2025.
Support GP training in telephone consultation, triage, and urgent care including appendicitis differential diagnosis.

responses.respondent: President of the Royal College of Radiologists
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Bottles of sevoflurane, whether unopened or partially used after theatre, do not appear to be robustly monitored to the degree that it was possible for a bottle of sevoflurane to be removed from Cannock Chase Hospital without this being flagged by the auditing system.

action_phrases: Plan to look at risk reduction strategies including improved use of automation and ensuring storage, recording and audit processes are robust.
Will continue to explore and support improvements in controlled, authorised and auditable access to medicines.

concern_responses.concern: The trust was unable to confirm or refute that the bottle found at the deceased’s home address originated from Cannock Chase Hospital.

action_phrases: [no response]
Will consider the hospital’s response and any actions arising from this in due course.

receiver: Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents

concern_responses.concern: Greater awareness of the phenomenon of aquaplaning is important for road users.

action_phrases: Will consider including advice on aquaplaning in the next Highway Code revision consultation
Provides advice on aquaplaning in driving tests and publishes guidance for all drivers

responses.respondent: Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents
action_phrases: Will create and share digital education materials on aquaplaning awareness through social media and website by Q2 2025

concern_responses.concern: There is a need to reduce speed when surface water is present on the road.

action_phrases: Highlights Rule 125 of the Highway Code advising reducing speed when road conditions present hazards including wet weather
Includes guidance on reducing speed in wet conditions within driver education and published materials

responses.respondent: Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Basic knowledge about braking and steering should be provided to drivers in case a vehicle experiences aquaplaning.

action_phrases: Notes Rules 117-126 of the Highway Code cover vehicle control including skidding and steering in wet conditions
Ensures driving tests and guidance include skills for handling aquaplaning and wet road conditions

responses.respondent: Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The Highway Code is currently silent on the matter of aquaplaning, which may leave road users uninformed.

action_phrases: Will consider including advice on aquaplaning in the next Highway Code revision consultation
Uses the Highway Code and DES as source materials for theory tests including aquaplaning content

responses.respondent: Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents
action_phrases: Will engage with Department for Transport and DVSA regarding coroner's findings by Q4 2024

receiver: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care

concern_responses.concern: National targets for ambulance response times continue not to be adhered to, as evidenced by the anticipated wait for a Category 3 ambulance on 1 June 2024 being around 3 hours and 15 minutes, exceeding the target of 9 out of 10 responses within 120 minutes.

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care
action_phrases: Publish the 10-Year Health Plan in Spring 2025 focusing on reforms to improve NHS performance including ambulance response times.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: The current wording of some of the script used by Call Handlers under NHS Pathways creates an impression that an ambulance has been dispatched when this is not the case, with phrases such as ‘An emergency ambulance has been arranged’, ‘we will be with you as soon as possible, as soon as an ambulance is available’ and ‘if you can ask for someone to meet and direct the vehicle and shut any dogs away if there are any’ potentially misleading callers.

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care
action_phrases: [no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: Under the NHS Pathways paradigm, there is potential for an ambulance response to be cancelled without this first being discussed with the person who dialed 999 and requested an ambulance.

action_phrases: Confirm that ambulance cancellations are managed locally with Standard Operating Procedures outside NHS Pathways system.

responses.respondent: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care
action_phrases: [no response]

responses.respondent: Operations Director, Tenancy and Homeowner Services, London Borough of Hackney
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The leaseholder of [REDACTED] was not aware of any work being undertaken to the guttering or drainpipes to the block following Ms McGreevy’s death.

responses.respondent: Operations Director, Tenancy and Homeowner Services, London Borough of Hackney
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: In the absence of remedial works, the practice of residents unblocking pipes themselves is likely to continue.

responses.respondent: Operations Director, Tenancy and Homeowner Services, London Borough of Hackney
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The pedestrian crossing area across Jersey Road is an uncontrolled crossing with no pedestrian traffic lights, no demand button, and no sound signals, despite spanning a dual carriageway with a 40mph speed limit and three lanes in both directions.

action_phrases: Developing a formal signalised crossing proposal including push button unit, rotating cone, and green person signal for pedestrians and cyclists across the A4 and Jersey Road.
Working with TfL to consult on and ensure new signal-controlled pedestrian and cyclist crossings meet local users' needs, aiming for design finalisation in 2025-26.
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: The crossing point leads pedestrians into the cycling lane, creating additional risk for pedestrians.

action_phrases: Designing the crossing area as a shared space with signage to encourage respect between pedestrians and cyclists, subject to engagement.
[no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: During normal use of the traffic light controlled junction, traffic does not cease to flow at the marked crossing area, making it difficult for pedestrians to judge when and from where the next vehicle will approach, requiring pedestrians to use their own judgement to cross safely without pedestrian traffic lights.

action_phrases: Proposing new pedestrian crossing design to hold traffic on the A4, allowing pedestrians time to cross safely with signalised facilities.
[no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: There have been other accidents involving pedestrians and moving vehicles at this pedestrian crossing in the past.

action_phrases: Conducted thorough review of historic collision data and considering additional highway layout changes to reduce collision risk.
[no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: Although TFL has existing plans to redesign this pedestrian crossing to improve safety, implementation may not occur before the end of 2026 and remains subject to the consent of the DFT and LBH, public consultation outcomes, and funding considerations.

action_phrases: Aiming to implement the proposed crossing improvements in 2026 after traffic modelling, public engagement, design, and contractor mobilisation.
Continuing to work with TfL and stakeholders to secure priority implementation of safety measures expected in 2026-27.
Clarified no consent or approvals are required from DfT for the crossing redesign; funding is managed by TfL.

concern_responses.concern: There is no certainty that the redesign plans for the pedestrian crossing will be implemented.

action_phrases: Committing to monitor operation and performance of new crossings for at least 48 months post-implementation including safety audits.
[no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: The TFL, LBH, and DFT are the organisations with the power to take necessary actions to improve pedestrian safety at this junction.

action_phrases: Leading the design and delivery of formal pedestrian crossings and working with LBH on minor works to improve safety at the junction.
Collaborating with TfL to review and approve designs and facilitate interim safety measures like additional signage.
Providing guidance and clarifying that no consent is required for TfL's safety improvements; funding is TfL's responsibility.

receiver: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence

concern_responses.concern: There was no national guidance to assist clinicians in primary care in assessing whether to consider prolonging the course of anti-coagulation prescribed in secondary care for elderly immobile patients such as Mrs Lambert to reduce the ongoing risk of developing a fatal DVT in the community.

responses.respondent: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence
action_phrases: We will review our guidance on stopping and starting VTE prophylaxis to see if an update is warranted, potentially covering management of immobility.

concern_responses.concern: Maintaining ketamine's classification as a class B drug is likely to encourage others to start or continue using it under the false impression it is safer due to its lower classification compared to class A drugs.

responses.respondent: Minister of State for Policing, Fire and Crime Prevention
action_phrases: Intend to commission the ACMD to conduct an updated harms assessment of ketamine as part of the forthcoming three-year work programme commission cycle

concern_responses.concern: Ketamine use causes huge long-term life-changing health problems, including long-term urological and liver damage, which in Mr Boland's case led to his death.

responses.respondent: Minister of State for Policing, Fire and Crime Prevention
action_phrases: Intend to commission the ACMD to conduct an updated harms assessment of ketamine as part of the forthcoming three-year work programme commission cycle

concern_responses.concern: There is a significant increase in the illicit use of ketamine leading to a rise in potentially fatal health problems seen by clinicians, with the extent of these risks rarely understood by users until the damage has been done to their health.

responses.respondent: Minister of State for Policing, Fire and Crime Prevention
action_phrases: Intend to commission the ACMD to conduct an updated harms assessment of ketamine as part of the forthcoming three-year work programme commission cycle

receiver: Secretary of State for Housing, Communities, and Local Government

concern_responses.concern: There is a lack of accommodation available to the Probation Service in which prisoners released from custody may properly be placed, including both Approved Premises (which are the responsibility of the MoJ) and more generally through the local authority to avoid homelessness.

responses.respondent: Ministry of Justice and Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government
action_phrases: Expanded Approved Premises by 169 spaces and increased women's provision by over 30% to improve accommodation availability.

concern_responses.concern: As a consequence of the lack of suitable accommodation, some prisoners are released and become effectively homeless, which increases difficulties in supervision.

responses.respondent: Ministry of Justice and Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government
action_phrases: Provide CAS3 transitional accommodation with 2603 bedspaces expanding annually to support prison leavers at risk of homelessness.

concern_responses.concern: Some prisoners are accommodated at unsuitable premises, as happened in this instance.

responses.respondent: Ministry of Justice and Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government
action_phrases: Homelessness Prevention Teams coordinate multi-agency efforts to identify appropriate accommodation pathways for prison leavers.

receiver: The Chief Executive Officer of the Coventry and Warwickshire Partnership Trust

concern_responses.concern: Section 17 leave conditions may not always be thoroughly reviewed or clarified before a service user is signed out for leave, leading to unaddressed discrepancies that may impact the safety and appropriateness of unescorted leave.

action_phrases: Updated Section 17 Leave Policy with cross-directorate input and provided a Section 17 toolkit on the Trust intranet including step-by-step guidance and checklists.

concern_responses.concern: There may be a lack of accessible or reliable means for service users on unescorted leave to contact the facility if they encounter difficulties, impacting their ability to seek support or assistance when needed.

action_phrases: Developed and implemented a 'contact card' with key phone numbers for patients accessing leave to ensure they can seek help if needed.

concern_responses.concern: The reporting system may have limitations in identifying and addressing substantive issues that directly impact patient safety, risking that critical concerns are overlooked and valuable insights for preventing future incidents are missed, reducing the system's effectiveness in promoting long-term safety improvements.

action_phrases: Transitioned from Serious Incident Framework to Patient Safety Incident Response Framework using NHS England’s PSIRF toolkit and engaged external consultancy for staff training and policy development.

concern_responses.concern: The delay of information relating to what has been prescribed to an individual being sent to the GP surgery by voluntary and NHS organisations.

action_phrases: Implement national adoption of interoperable medicine standards by June 2025 to improve medication information transfer to GP records.

receiver: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council

concern_responses.concern: Carers at times spent no more than 15 minutes, on one occasion 8 minutes, with Ms Townend, which was not an adequate time to conduct tasks including preparing meals, conducting personal care if required, and talking to the service user, considering Early Warning Signs and document keeping.

action_phrases: Received an action plan from the provider addressing the duration of staff visits and will undertake an unannounced assessment including staff having adequate time to meet people’s needs.
[no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not escalate any concerns when Ms Townend was not eating, despite her comorbidities and risk of infection making nutrition very important.

action_phrases: Received an action plan from the provider addressing nutrition and hydration and will undertake an unannounced assessment including how staff identify changing needs and escalate concerns.
[no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not escalate any concerns when Ms Townend was unwell with sickness, despite multiple occasions of her presenting as having been sick.

action_phrases: Received an action plan from the provider addressing how staff will monitor people’s health and well-being and will undertake an unannounced assessment including support for healthier lives and care monitoring.
[no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not accurately record concerns regarding Early Warning Signs (EWS) or escalate when they were present, always recording EWS as no concerns even when Ms Townend displayed signs that should have been escalated.

action_phrases: Received an action plan from the provider addressing staff training, oversight of records and processes for escalating concerns and will undertake an unannounced assessment including record keeping and governance.
[no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Carers did not follow up with Ms Townend when she indicated she was seeking GP support as she was feeling unwell; subsequent carers did not enquire whether this had been done despite it being recorded in the Observation Log.

action_phrases: Received an action plan from the provider addressing systems for monitoring people’s health effectively and will undertake an unannounced assessment including governance and care oversight.
[no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Although Ms Townend was deemed to have capacity, carers did not escalate concerns when she made unwise decisions to refuse personal care, decline food, and decline medical intervention, resulting in her sitting in her own faeces and becoming weak without consideration for reassessment of her capacity.

action_phrases: Received an action plan from the provider addressing staff understanding of the mental capacity act and will undertake an unannounced assessment including safeguarding and decision making.
[no response]

responses.respondent: Adult Social Services, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: [no response]

receiver: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council

concern_responses.concern: The quality of the review following referrals to Adults Safeguarding from Yorkshire Ambulance Service and Hull Royal Infirmary was lacking.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Implemented a new service and practice model with improved forms and training since November 2023 to support good safeguarding practice.

concern_responses.concern: The Safeguarding Adult Review did not appropriately probe the responses received from the care company and the Community Nurses.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Addressed practice issues with the individual practitioner and disseminated lessons learned within the team.

concern_responses.concern: The procedure adopted for the review did not record how the responses had been obtained, and the family's input was not recorded.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Launched new forms guiding practitioners to record enquiry methodology and include the voice of the person and family at the heart of the record.

concern_responses.concern: The review process happened hastily and was not to the appropriate standards that would have been of any benefit.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Implemented a training programme and weekly practice forum to support high quality safeguarding enquiry practice.

concern_responses.concern: The outcomes of the review and recommendations were not provided to the subjects of the review.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Introduced new paperwork requiring workers to share outcomes and recommendations with relevant parties and monitor compliance.

concern_responses.concern: There was a lack of professional curiosity and the full review process was not followed or documented properly.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Accompanied new forms with guidance encouraging professional curiosity and thorough enquiry recording.

concern_responses.concern: The procedure conducted for Safeguarding reviews needs to be looked at to avoid any impact on anyone else, as these reviews are important to identify concerns and prevent future issues.

responses.respondent: Safeguarding Adults Team, East Riding of Yorkshire Council
action_phrases: Remodelled safeguarding adults service with a dedicated hub and locality teams to ensure robust, person-centred enquiries and continuous improvement.

concern_responses.concern: No evidence has been presented as to the knowledge of Henry Joseph Grierson's discontinuation of referral and treatment from CAMHS and his intention to discharge himself from Recovery Steps by the safeguarding team at Huddersfield New College.

action_phrases: [no response]
[no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: No information concerning the current mental health issues of Mr Grierson had been provided to Huddersfield New College within a mitigation statement provided by him.

action_phrases: [no response]
[no response]

concern_responses.concern: Communication between Huddersfield New College and CAMHS and Recovery Steps was not seemingly maintained to enable an awareness by the college of the current mental health of Mr Grierson in April 2024 and the decisions taken by himself and his family to remove such external support.

action_phrases: [no response]
[no response]
[no response]

receiver: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council

concern_responses.concern: The path at the location of Mrs Friedhoff’s accident is only about 2 metres wide, which is significantly narrower than the national guidance of 3.5 metres for such a path, creating an obvious accident risk for pedestrians and cyclists.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The path is a shared space heavily used by cyclists for leisure and commuting, some traveling at significant speed in close proximity to pedestrians, despite cyclists not being permitted to use the footpath unless they have permission.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Organise promotional events from spring 2025 highlighting safe and responsible towpath use including cyclist behaviour.

concern_responses.concern: The surface of the path has been upgraded in recent years, which has probably encouraged increased use by cyclists and enabled them to cycle faster, increasing the risk of serious injury to pedestrians.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Carry out monitoring of cycle and pedestrian use including speed in spring/summer 2025 to inform interventions.

concern_responses.concern: There is a lack of clear mitigating measures such as signage reminding users, particularly cyclists, of the need to take care and slow down around pedestrians.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: Audit and review signage in winter/early 2025 with implementation of additional signage by summer 2025.

concern_responses.concern: Enforcement is weak, as Environment Agency signs prohibit cyclists from cycling through locks but cyclists do so nevertheless, and enforcement focusing on speed is difficult.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Physical measures such as gates or similar to slow cyclists have not been implemented, which could reduce the risk of accidents.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: Segregation lines have not been applied, likely due to the narrow width of the path, which limits options for separating pedestrians and cyclists.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: The path has not been reconfigured to redirect through the small woods present at the location, which may offer an opportunity to create two separate paths, one gated for pedestrians and one for cyclists.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: [no response]

concern_responses.concern: There is a risk that accidents similar to Mrs Friedhoff’s may continue to occur that could result in death, indicating the need for a safety review by OCC in conjunction with the Environment Agency and other stakeholders.

responses.respondent: Director of Highways and Operations Oxfordshire County Council
action_phrases: [no response]

receiver: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, Department of Health and Social Care

concern_responses.concern: On discharge from the medical ward, there was no mental health bed available for Mr Singh, resulting in him being accommodated in a Travel Lodge or sleeping rough.

responses.respondent: Minister with responsibility for mental health and patient safety
action_phrases: Published statutory guidance on Discharge from mental health inpatient settings in January 2024 to support safe and timely discharge decisions
Directed systems to reduce average length of stay in adult acute mental health wards to deliver more timely access to local beds

concern_responses.concern: There is a chronic shortage of mental health beds, described as a crisis, affecting availability not just in London but nationally.

responses.respondent: Minister with responsibility for mental health and patient safety
action_phrases: Invested in new units and developed community mental health framework to improve support and reduce inpatient admissions
Allocated £42 million recurrent investment from 2024/25 for Integrated Care Boards to recommission inpatient care aligned with local models

receiver: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

concern_responses.concern: Mrs Tromans' Waterlow score was underestimated on admission, leading to a failure to identify her very high risk of pressure sores during her almost 18-hour stay in the Emergency Department where she was positioned on a trolley without pressure area care.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Implement targeted ED staff training, new pressure-relieving trolley mattresses, pillows for heel offloading, updated Waterlow score booklet, skin champions, and trolley mattress audits

concern_responses.concern: The repositioning schedule requiring repositioning at no greater intervals than four hours was not adhered to on 22 occasions, resulting in Mrs Tromans being left in the same position for up to 14 hours.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Conduct weekly repositioning audits in AMU with real-time feedback, hold Tissue Viability Link Worker training events, and implement the Response Assessment Tool for compliance

concern_responses.concern: The paper version of the wound care plan on East Ground B ward, designed for detailed monitoring and treatment of pressure sores, was not completed at any stage.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Use updated Wound Assessment Chart with staff training and monitor usage through patient assessments and quarterly audits

concern_responses.concern: The Matron's investigation into the gaps in care did not seek to establish why they had occurred, raising concerns about the quality and efficacy of the Trust's post-death investigations and potential risks for future deaths.

responses.respondent: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
action_phrases: Revise investigation process to include individual staff statements and embed findings into roundtable reports with shared learning and regular leadership updates
